Profile.nme: Backup Task Descriptions When They Change

Share.d:
Use ChatGPT to control your phone using Tasker and Natural Language!

Check out the video demo for this project here!

Before You Get Started

The ChatGPT API is a paid service, but for Tasker uses it seems like a very cheap service.

Even so, OpenAI controls the amount of requests you can do based on your budget. If you hit any quota limits, please contact OpenAI about it, since Tasker can't control that part.

Also, start by generating an API Key here so you have it handy to paste it into the prompt that shows up when you import this project.

What It Does

This project allows you to use ChatGPT's impressive language understanding capabilities and use them to run your Tasker tasks in an intelligent way.

Simply describe your tasks in the built-in tool, then say what you want in natural language and ChatGPT will figure out what it needs to call!

You can even return values back to ChatGPT so that it can tell you any info you want, like your phone's battery level or anything else really!

How to Get Started

  • Import this project and insert the ChatGPT API key when prompted.
  • Import this Example Tasks project, so that you have easy to understand examples you can follow
  • Run the ChatGPT Function Setup task so that you can add descriptions to the tasks you want ChatGPT to be able to run. If you imported the Examples project and ran its setup task, notice how those tasks already have descriptions.
  • Run the ChatGPT Voice Task and try saying something like Toggle the flashlight. ChatGPT will now select the Toggle Flashlight task to run and run it!
  • Try running the other example tasks and see how they work! Remember that you can use natural language to run them! No need to be precise!

Important Notes

  • Multi-language support: you can use this in any language that ChatGPT understands. The descriptions can even be in one language and you can still do your voice commands in a different language!
  • Replace Your System Assistant: go into Tasker > Menu > More > Android Settings > Assistant Settings and make Tasker your assistant. Now you can do voice commands with ChatGPT directly!
  • Add As a Home Screen Shortcut/Widget: to add any of the tasks as home screen shortcuts, long-touch your Home Launcher app, select Add Widget/Shortcut (or something similar) and then select the Tasker Shortcut widget. Note: some launchers do not support shortcuts.
  • Add as Quick Setting Tile: you can run the included ChatGPT Set Voice Task Quick Setting task to make your first Tasker Quick Setting run the Voice Task in this project, so you can quickly call it from anywhere!
  • This project has a Project Variable that you can access by opening Tasker, touching the ChatGPT Task Caller project name and going to Properties. If you ever need to change it, do it here.
  • Your task descriptions will be backed up in the Tasker/ChatGPT folder.

Task.nme: ChatGPT Task Caller Set GPT Version

Action.Str: 3.5 Turbo - faster and cheaper, but less precise/worse responses
4 - slower and more expensive, but usually much better responses (you need to have access to it on https://platform.openai.com/playground)

Vals.net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VA: <StringArray sr=""><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES0>%http_cookies Cookies The cookies the server sent in the response in the Cookie:COOKIE_VALUE format. You can use this directly in the 'Headers' field of the HTTP Request action</_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES0><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES1>%http_file_output File Output Will always contain the file's full path even if you specified a directory as the File to save.</_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES1><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES2>%http_response_code Response Code The HTTP Code the server responded</_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES2><_array_net.dinglisch.android.tasker.RELEVANT_VARIABLES3>%http_headers() Response Headers The HTTP Headers the server sent in the response.
